stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on Course 15, “Astral Arcade.”  The session is almost entirely devoted to brainstorming, modeling, and planning a set of 3-D pinball elements (flippers, bumpers, trampolines, platforms) that will float beneath the main playfield.  He also chats about a pending side-commission, sponsorship oddities, and personal trivia.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 will follow a Mario-Galaxy style: an open space that actually guides the player along discrete, intersecting paths.  The main arena sits above a cluster of pinball pieces that shoot Mario back upward.
development_findings.quote: It will feel open but be linear, like Galaxy—random linear paths that intersect, and below the main area the flipper pieces shoot you back up.

development_findings.summary: Current milestone is to 3-D model and program five pinball elements:  a rotating flipper paddle, a spherical (or half-spherical) omni-bumper, a triangular directional bumper, a trampoline/button pad, and static metal platforms.
development_findings.quote: Once the level is done, we have a few actors done, but there's still some stuff to do. Right now I'm looking for flipper pieces.

development_findings.summary: Design constraint: the pieces must function in full 3-D; many classic 2-D pinball gimmicks (speed stripes, coin targets) are being discarded or re-imagined.
development_findings.quote: We have to keep in mind that the ones we make have to work in 3-D space, so we can't do all of this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze wrestles with how to visually communicate “this will bump you” on a sphere; a full sphere looks bad, so he is leaning toward a half-sphere with springs and billboarded rings for feedback.
development_findings.quote: Not the hemisphere? …But the non-hemisphere is just impossible. Probably common because the other way is impossible.

development_findings.summary: Visual style goals: glowing accents, floating geometry, transparent decals, space metal; all pieces will probably emit light and pulse when activated.
development_findings.quote: It has to glow and as soon as you land on it, it should shoot you up.

development_findings.summary: Workflow: Kaze prototypes the geometry; Biobak will later polish textures and overall look.
development_findings.quote: I'm sure Biobak will improve this anyway; for now this flipper piece is fine.

development_findings.summary: A previously commissioned ‘GTA-style’ Mario hack has been re-funded, forcing Kaze to split time and slowing Return to Yoshi’s Island progress.
development_findings.quote: That hack is going to keep me very busy over the next few days, unfortunately, so I can only get little work done on RTYI.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is increasingly irritated by YouTube comments and general online feedback.
context_findings.quote: I don't know what it is, but recently I've been getting so much more annoyed at my YouTube comments.

context_findings.summary: He works in an uncomfortably cold room, a recurring physical grievance.
context_findings.quote: It's so fucking cold in my room. I wish there was a way to make it warm, but there isn't.

context_findings.summary: Kaze samples free sunflower-seed snacks on stream and is evaluating a potential affiliate deal.
context_findings.quote: They gave me a bunch of really good flavors… I imagine they will still tell me what I'm supposed to do.

context_findings.summary: He received a bizarre sponsorship request for a custom dildo based on his anatomy and finds it hilarious but declines.
context_findings.quote: They want pictures. This is asking me for cock pics, bro—what?

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes he was “born with the ability to program” and only needed to learn syntax.
context_findings.quote: Programming is not something I had to learn… I was really just born with the ability to program.

context_findings.summary: Legal caution: he refuses to distribute beta builds via Patreon because it could be interpreted as selling Nintendo IP.
context_findings.quote: I can't give people access because that would basically be selling access to the game, which would be really bad legally.

biobak.summary: Will take Kaze’s placeholder pinball geometry and improve textures and visual quality.
biobak.quote: I'm sure Biobak will improve this anyway.

key_stories.title: The Impossible Bumper
key_stories.summary: Kaze needs a 3-D bumper that instantly communicates ‘bounce.’ Full spheres look ugly and unreadable, but half-spheres feel cliché.
key_stories.challenge: Translating a 2-D pinball bumper into clear 3-D form factor.
key_stories.process: Iterated textures, tried transparent decals, glowing rings, springs, and billboarded stars; consulted chat for references; weighed hemisphere vs. full sphere.
key_stories.outcome: Tentative decision to switch to a half-sphere with attached springs and reactive glow, pending Biobak’s polish.
key_stories.key_quote: I think I'm going with a half sphere instead of a full sphere—take the L, it's not gonna work out.

key_stories.title: Resurrected Commission
key_stories.summary: An old, edgy ‘Mario GTA’ hack client paid again, obligating Kaze to finish it.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing a paid side project with the main Return to Yoshi’s Island schedule.
key_stories.process: Demonstrated features (drug sales, NPC violence) on stream; acknowledged time sink.
key_stories.outcome: Will dominate his next few off-stream days, slowing current level work.
key_stories.key_quote: That hack is going to keep me very busy over the next few days, unfortunately.

key_stories.title: The Sex-Toy Sponsorship Email
key_stories.summary: Kaze receives an email from a company offering to clone his anatomy for a commercial dildo.
key_stories.challenge: Deciding how to respond to an absurd sponsorship proposal.
key_stories.process: Reads the email aloud, jokes about verification issues and potential trolling.
key_stories.outcome: Rejects the offer but shares it as comedic content; sparks chat discussion.
key_stories.key_quote: They want this—asking me for cock pics, bro—what?

open_questions.topic: Final look and behavior of the bumper sphere
open_questions.context: Kaze ended the stream undecided, with several prototype ideas on screen.
questions: Have you settled on half-sphere, full sphere, or another design?
What visual and audio cues will make it unmistakably ‘bouncy’?
Any technical hurdles in coding omni-directional force on N64 hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze relies on Biobak to ‘improve’ placeholder models but no timetable given.
questions: At what stage do models move from Kaze to Biobak?
How do you two iterate—shared files, Fast64, live calls?
What are Biobak’s guiding principles for Astral Arcade’s palette?

open_questions.topic: Impact of the commissioned ‘GTA’ hack on RtYI schedule
open_questions.context: Kaze said the side project will occupy several days.
questions: How many hours per week can still go to Return to Yoshi’s Island?
What milestones (if any) will be delayed?
Could elements or tech from the commission benefit RtYI later?

open_questions.topic: Extra 1 MB memory and cache optimizations
open_questions.context: Kaze teased upcoming videos about using an additional megabyte of RAM and better cache use.
questions: Will these optimizations be integrated into Return to Yoshi’s Island?
What practical gains (larger levels, more actors, higher frame rate) do you anticipate?
Any risks to emulator or hardware compatibility?

open_questions.context: Kaze reiterated he cannot sell beta access but gave no alternative plan.
questions: How will the team handle public testing without crossing Nintendo's legal line?
Is there a target release window for Return to Yoshi’s Island?
What contingency plans exist if Nintendo issues a takedown?
